thread.title: Japan aims to continue incredible RWC journey into last 8
thread.title_full: Japan aims to continue incredible RWC journey into last 8

author: JEROME PUGMIRE
title: Japan aims to continue incredible RWC journey into last 8
text:
Japan aims to continue incredible RWC journey into last 8 By JEROME PUGMIRE -   
LONDON (AP) - With every match on Japan’s Rugby World Cup journey, millions more people tune in back home to follow the Brave Blossoms. 
Imagine where it could lead if Japan reaches the quarterfinals. 
To get through, Japan needs to beat last-place United States in Pool B on Sunday night in the very last match of the pool stage, while relying on Samoa to beat Scotland on Saturday. 
“This game for us will be the most difficult and most important,” Japan captain Michael Leitch said. “We have to get ourselves right mentally. We can’t worry about Saturday’s result.” 
Even if coach Eddie Jones’ players don’t progress to the knockout stage, they’re among the stars of the World Cup. 
It all started on the first weekend of the tournament, on a sunny afternoon on the English south coast, when Japan stunned two-time champion South Africa with a 34-32 win in Brighton. It turned the form-guide upside down. 
Japan had previously only won one World Cup match. Now they’re aiming for three in four matches. 
Suddenly, rugby, a niche sport in a country where baseball, soccer and sumo wrestling dominate, is in vogue. 
Last Saturday, 25 million people watched on TV as Japan beat Samoa 26-5. 
That beat the previous national TV audience record for a Rugby World Cup match - set by the French for their team’s loss to England in the 2007 semifinals - by more than four million. 
If Samoa does Japan a favor and beats the Scots, then the TV viewing record could well be eclipsed on Sunday night - even if the 8 p.m. kick off local time in Gloucester is 4 a.m. in Tokyo. 
Here’s a look at Sunday’s four games at the Rugby World Cup: 
___ 
ARGENTINA vs. NAMIBIA (2-0, both in RWC), Leicester, 1100 GMT 
Argentina has already qualified for the quarterfinals, courtesy of New Zealand’s win over Tonga on Friday, and selected a team with that in mind.
